Problem:
Consider a function \\( z(t) \\) where \\( z(t) = \int_0^t e^{i\omega s} ds \\). Here, \\( i \\) is the imaginary unit and \\( \omega \\) is a constant real number.

Does increasing \\( \omega \\) lead to a decrease in the magnitude of \\( z(t) \\) at a fixed time \\( t \\), without any external intervention?
Explanation: The integral \\( z(t) \\) represents the area under the curve of the complex exponential. Increasing \\( \omega \\) increases the frequency of oscillations within the interval [0, t], which leads to more cancellations in the integral of the sine and cosine components, effectively reducing the magnitude of \\( z(t) \\).
